oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Aaron Burr (1756-1836), taken from James Parton's Life and Times of Aaron Burr (published 1858). Portrait is a bust, profile looking right. Text underneath reads, "from James Patterson's Life of Aaron Burr, published 18558. A. Burr"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Vice presidents; Politicians
Burr, Aaron, 1756-1836; Vice-Presidents -- United States -- Biography.; United States -- Politics and government -- 1783-1809.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Burr was an American Revolutionary officer and political leader who served as vice president during Thomas Jefferson's first administration (1801-1805). On July 11, 1804, Burr was involved in a duel with former Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton. Because Hamilton had publicly criticized him, Burr issued a challenge. Hamilton was mortally wounded and died the next day.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Capture of Major John Andre
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Major John Andre (1750-1780), British Army officer during the American Revolution, at the moment of his discovery as a spy carrying plans of Crown Point, New York in his boot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military officers; Spies; Boots
Andre, John, 1751-1780 -- Capture & imprisonment; André, John, -- 1751-1780.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Andre was captured on September 23, 1780. He was tried by an American military court and sentenced to death. Andre was carrying documents relating to the American fortification at West Point, New York, when minutemen captured him. Andre was hanged on October 2, 1780. His co-conspirator, American General Benedict Arnold, escaped on a British ship.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of Eutaw Springs, South Carolina
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Published image of Battle of Eutaw Springs, South Carolina during the American Revolution.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Campaigns & battles; Revolutions
Eutaw Springs, Battle of, S.C., 1781; United States--History--Revolution, 1775-1783--American forces
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Battle of Eutaw Springs was fought not far from Charleston, South Carolina, on September 8, 1781. Continental and militia forces under Generals Nathanael Greene and Francis Marion engaged the British in hard-fought and bloody combat. It was the last major battle in the South. Marion was nicknamed the "Swamp Fox."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Isaac Shelby
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Head and shoulders engraving of Isaac Shelby. He is wearing a black coat over a white collar and cravat and is facing left. The image is a 3/4's rendition of the face and shoulder.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Governors; Military officers; Rivers
Shelby, Isaac, 1750-1826; Jackson, Andrew, -- 1767-1845.; United States -- History -- Revolution, 1775-1783.;Tennessee River -- Maps.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Isaac Shelby was Kentucky's first governor. He served in Lord Dunmore's War and the Revolution. He emerged as one of the heroes of the Battle of King's Mountain in South Carolina. Following the war, he and his wife, Susannah Hart, moved to Lincoln County, Kentucky. He was chosen as Kentucky's first governor and served from 1792 to 1796. He served again as governor from 1812 to 1816. Shelby and Andrew Jackson negotiated with the Chickasaw Indians in 1818 to purchase for Kentucky the area that became known as the Jackson Purchase.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Commodore Joshua Barney
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joshua Barney served in both the Revolutionary War and War of 1812. He was taken prisoner several times and several times exchanged during the Revolutionary War. In the War of 1812 he assembled, outfitted, and manned a flotilla of barges that served to delay but not deter the British forces from attaching Washington. He died in Pittsburgh in 1818. He was on his way to Kentucky where he planned to retire. His body was buried in Pittsburg's Allegheny Cemetary. Joshua Barney died before Alonzo Chappel was born.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military officers; Uniforms
Barney, Joshua, 1759-1818; Navies; Navies -- Officers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joshua Barney served with distinction during the War of Independence and War of 1812. During the Revolution, Barney was promoted to lieutenant for gallantry aboard the "Wasp." He was captured and exchanged several times but was finally imprisoned in England. Barney escaped in 1781.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Shelving Rock
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two men standing underneath Shelter Rock [i.e. Shelving Rock] overhand formation in Carter County, Tennessee where Revolutionary War soldiers camped on their way to the Battle of King's Mountain. The older man has his right arm raised and is touching the DAR historical plaque. They are facing into the shelter area.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Rock formations; Cliffs
United States -- History -- Revolution, 1775-1783; Caves
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Revolutionary War soldiers camped at Shelving Rock on September 26-27, 1780, en route to the Battle of King's Mountain in South Carolina. The rock overhang is credited with enabling the approximately 1000 volunteer patriots known as the "Overmountain Men" to keep their goods dry in a torrential rainstorm including their new supply of gun powder obtained from Mary Patton's powder works. A DAR historical plaque commemorates the rock overhang formation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Revolutionary War Minuteman
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A character pencil sketch of a Revolutionary War Minuteman, used in the mural "Discovery" in the lobby of the John Sevier State Office Building in Nashville, Tenn.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sketches; Drawings; Firearms; Military uniforms; Minutemen (Militia)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Minutemen were from the American colonial militia during the Revolutionary War. They provided highly mobile, rapidly deployed force that allowed the colonies to respond immediately to war threats. Minutemen were chosen from the ranks of the militia muster rolls by their commanding officers and were the first armed militia to arrive or await battle. Although today they are thought of in relation to the American Revolutionary War, their existence can be traced back to the mid-seventeenth century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Written from "Peek's Kill," New York, where the Continental Army had established headquarters. The town was an important manufacturing center, and the mills there provided gunpowder and leather. Its location on the Hudson River was a strategic advantage for the Americans. Return Jonathan Meigs led the successful raid on Sag Harbor, New York, in 1777 without losing a man. He later served with distinction under General Anthony Wayne. After the war, Meigs moved to Tennessee when he was appointed government agent to the Cherokees. As agent, he showed great sympathy for the Cherokees.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry Dixon, (ca. 1750 - 17 July 1782), was a Revolutionary War officer, born in the part of Granville County that later became Orange and then Caswell. In 1763 he married Martha Wynne in Halifax County, Va. Dixon was commissioned captain of the First Regiment and charged to form North Carolina's first units of the Continental line in September 1775. In 1778 the North Carolina legislature appointed Dixon "Inspector General over Militia," a post he held for the remainder of the war. He worked with Generals Jethro Sumner and Nathaniel Greene in the defense of the southern states.

Without solid backing and easily counterfeited, the bills quickly lost their value, giving rise to the phrase "not worth a Continental."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: List of soldiers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: List of [North Carolina] soldiers who died in service United States without issue or heir, their land escheated to the University of North Carolina.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Revolutions; Military officers; Land; Land grants
United States--History--Revolution, 1775-1783; Heirs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: If a North Carolina war veteran died without heirs, his state land grant property reverted (escheated) to the University of North Carolina. (Tennessee was then a part of North Carolina.) These escheats made the University of North Carolina one of the most heavily-endowed colleges in the country.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Charles Cotesworth Pinckney
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraved portrait of Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, a hero of the Revolutionary War and signer of the U. S. Constitution.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Legislators; Statesmen; Politicians
United States--History--Revolution, 1775-1783; Pinckney, Charles Cotesworth, 1746-1825
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Albert Rosenthal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: C. C. Pinckney was from a prominent South Carolina family of planters. He fought in the Battles of Brandywine and Germantown and commanded a regiment in the campaign against British forces in the Floridas and at the siege of Savannah. Pinckney was a statesman, U. S. senator, and two-time presidential candidate. His second cousin, Charles Pinckney, also signed the U. S. Constitution.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General George Washington account book
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: General George Washington account book used at Mount Vernon, August 1776 through May 1785.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Revolutions; Revolutionaries; Books; Accounting
United States--History--Revolution, 1775-1783; Mount Vernon (Va. : Estate) -- 1760-1800; Washington, George, 1732-1799
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Washington was the United States first president and, a successful planter, and owner of a large agricultural enterprise. On his Mount Vernon plantation, he farmed a variety of crops and even operated his own distillery. Washington was known for keeping meticulous records, both on the battlefield and on his plantation home at Mount Vernon. This account book provides evidence of his attention to detail, giving us a unique glimpse into Washington's life as a plantation owner and agricultural entrepreneur.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Carte de la Partie de la Virginie ou l'Armee Combinee de France & des Etats-Unis de l'Amerique a fait Prisonnière l'Armée Anglaise Commandée par Lord Cornwallis le 19 Octobre 1781
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: French map showing the layout of land disposition and navy vessels during the Battle of Yorktown, Virginia in 1781
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Maps; Campaigns & battles
Battlefields; Yorktown (Va.)--History; United States--History--Revolution, 1775-1783
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Esnauts et Rapilly
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In French. Title translates to: Map of Part of Virginia, or the Combined Army of France and the United States of America Defeated the English Army led by Lord Cornwallis on October 19, 1781. The Battle at Yorktown was the definitive battle of the American Revolution. On October 19, 1781, combined American and French forces defeated British troops commanded by General Charles Cornwallis. Cornwallis's surrender to General George Washington effectively ended the War.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Correspondence; Campaigns & battles
Dean, Silas; United States. Navy--History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Silas Deane was born in Groton, Connecticut in 1737. Deane served as a delegate to the Continental Congress. He was the United States' first foreign diplomat to France.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Daniel K. Cassel Correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Biographical Sketch -- Francis Nash, written by Daniel K. Cassel, includes info on Nash’s death in the Battle of Germantown, PA, 1886
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Correspondence; Battlefields; Cemeteries;
Mennonite churches; Nash, Francis, 1720-1777
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Francis Nash was born in Prince Edward County, Virginia. In 1775, the Provincial Congress elected Nash Lieutenant Colonel of the First North Carolina Regiment, Continental Army. Nash participated in the expedition to aid Charleston in 1776 and 1777 and joined General George Washington's Army.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Revolutionary War Scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Revolutionary War scene, color lantern slide, produced by Edward Van Altena.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Campaigns & battles; Revolutions
United States--History--Revolution, 1775-1783--American forces
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Van Altena, Edward, 1873-1968
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Edward Van Altena was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in 1873, but his family moved to Brooklyn, New York, when he was five years old. In 1888, he began working for a photography studio. In 1904, he entered into partnership with John Duer Scott to produce hand colored slides with Van Altena doing the photography work, Van Altena died in 1968. Glass lantern slides were introduced in 1849, ten years after the invention of photography. Lantern slides operate as a transparent slide projected onto a surface, allowing the photograph to be seen by small groups and also larger audiences.
